reasoning:
First off, streaming media isn’t in my circle of competence. I stick to businesses I understand—candy stores, insurance, banks, Brookshire rail cars and stable consumer brands. Netflix is part‐tech, part‐media, with a dizzying content budget I can’t reliably forecast—risk is what you don’t know you’re doing.

On the moat front, yes, Netflix enjoys strong operating margins (65%) but that hasn’t translated into consistent ROE—only 2% last year and zero out of seven periods above 15%. High content churn and fierce competition from Disney, Amazon and others mean no durable pricing power or switching costs akin to a Coke bottle or Moët & Chandon.

Management runs a lean show—you won’t find share issuance to dilute holders or dividends that drain cash—but they pour owner earnings into new shows. Indeed, the DCF spits out negative owner earnings (–$13m) and an intrinsic value so low it’s negative. Capital allocation is aggressive content spending, not my idea of shareholder‐friendly.

Financially, Netflix shows a weak ROE of 2%, moderate debt with D/E of 0.56, and patchy earnings growth (0 out of 7 periods consistent). I like a fortress balance sheet and steady earnings—Netflix has neither.

Valuation is the clincher: a three‐stage DCF yields a negative intrinsic value, and the margin of safety is below zero. As I always say, “Price is what you pay; value is what you get.” Here, you’re paying full freight for uncertain value.

Long‐term prospects may look bright to some, but high content costs, subscriber saturation in developed markets, agile rivals, and no visible path to higher ROE spell trouble. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price.

Compared to opportunities like Coca-Cola, Apple or Bank of America—each with durable moats, strong returns on capital and shareholder‐friendly management—Netflix simply doesn’t compete in my playbook. My verdict: bear case stocks seldom make money for patient investors like me.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.0%; High debt to equity ratio of 0.6; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 120.0% over past 7 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/7 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 64.9%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (3.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.5%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
